After reading Andrey Sitnik’s post on Autoprefixer, I knew I had to try out Grunt.js

I’ve done it all: Writing ‘vanilla’ CSS and adding vendor prefixes by hand, using Compass for its valuable mixins, using client-side tools like Lea Verou’s prefixfree.js. But nothing felt right.

I was spending too much time worrying about supporting my own browser (-webkit) instead of building kickass websites. I’ve finally found a workflow where I don’t have to worry about these things. I’m a big fan of Sass, and wanted to find a setup where the CSS processing was managed by one tool. I’m sad to say goodbye to CodeKit for now, but if you’re getting started out with Sass and/or other prepocessors, I recommend the application without hesitation. So let’s get to it!

Oh Hey, Grunt!

Next step, we’ll start a local Grunt project. If you don’t already have Grunt.js installed, check out the docs. To install the Grunt command line interface, we just need to run in the terminal:

 $ npm install -g grunt-cli

Next, we’ll get a local Grunt project started by adding a

package.json

{
  "name": "my-project-name",
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "devDependencies": {
    "grunt": "~0.4.1"
  }
}

and a basic ‘hello world’ Gruntfile.js just to make sure things are installed correctly.

Gruntfile.js

module.exports = function(grunt) {
  grunt.registerTask('default', 'just a basic hello world', function() {
    grunt.log.writeln('Grunt is installed and working!');
  });
};

At this point, you should be able to run

 $ grunt

and it will output ‘Grunt is installed and working’ in the console. View the code on GitHub.

Did it work?! Awesome!
